paragraphs: Transcript
Thanks for joining us here,
great to have you. My pleasure.
So this is Astro Teller, he oversees X,
which you may know is sort of colloquially thought of
as Alphabet's moonshot's division,
which that mean big bets, long time horizons.
Sure.
You tell me your definition of what X is.
So, X was created about 10 years ago to be the part of,
what was at the time Google, now Alphabet,
to hopefully make some new Googles for Alphabet,
things that could maybe be as good for the world
in the long run as Google has been,
and be as valuable to Alphabet as Google has been.
Moonshots are, for us, things
that have three basic elements.
There has to be a huge problem
in the world that you wanna fix
if you're gonna describe moonshot to us
and wanna take it on, what's that huge problem?
There has to be a radical proposed solution,
however unlikely it is that we could make that,
the science-fiction-sounding product or service,
if you could make it, it would fix
that huge problem in the world.
And then there needs to be some kind
of breakthrough technology that you can name
that makes it not completely crazy that we could make
that science-fiction-sounding product or service.
That's what a moonshot is to us
and that's what we spend our time on
is trying a lot of those things in the early stages,
most of them don't work out so we stop them.
Occasionally, they do work out enough
that we double down on them.
In their later stages, some of them still don't work out
but occasionally out the other side,
we produce things like Google Brain, Verily, Waymo,
Wing, Loon, Chronicle, Makani,
and I can go into detail about those.
But those are some of the examples of things
that have left X and gone on to become Alphabet companies.
So as you said it's been almost 10 years.
So in that time, have any kind of like guidelines emerged
for what works and what kinds of things
to do or not do?
Sure,
lots, I'm sure it would take more than the next 25 minutes
to describe all the things that we've learned.
It's been an exciting and complicated road.
But let me give you a few examples.
So one of them is long time horizons really matter.
And helping everyone feel
the long time horizon really matters.
Because if we have to solve a problem
in the next five minutes,
then there's no learning that's gonna go on.
Whatever it is that we're gonna do,
we're just gonna do it and hopefully it works.
If we have 1000 years between now
and when we have to solve a problem,
there's no way we don't spend the next couple
of generations just learning.
It doesn't matter how long it takes
and how much we mess around,
the learning's all that matters.
So how you define the time horizons for the project itself,
for the problem that you want to solve,
which is not the same as the project,
and for the people who you have.
If you're at X and you believe
that we're taking a 10-year horizon
on you as a professional at X,
you're gonna be managed differently
and you're gonna respond differently.
So that's an example that we suspected in the beginning
but it turned out to really matter.
What's a structural difference
in how X might implement that versus a normal company?
How do you actually bake that into the culture?
Well, as an example,
I get told regularly that I'm a little too Socratic
in my management style, and it's probably true
but it's also a time horizon thing.
So I will say to you, well, what are you thinking about?
How do you think that's gonna work?
And I have people come to me afterwards and say,
Astro, I was doing this thing
and you told me you didn't think it was gonna work out
but you didn't stop me.
And I say, I don't want to stop you
because if my goal was efficiency over the next quarter,
I'll just tell you what to do.
But I'm actually playing a 10-year process with you.
I want you to learn how to make these choices right
and even if I'm pretty positive what the right answer is,
I'll tell you what I believe,
but then I'm gonna empower you
to go do what you think is right,
you will then approach it with way more passion
than if I ordered you what to do,
and you're gonna learn faster too.
And if your gonna be with us for a decade,
I will make more money, Alphabet will make more money
because you went through that learning process
and you're gonna enjoy being a professional more.
So what's another guideline?
Another one is being passionately dispassionate.
Once you've created the opportunity
for learning with long time horizons,
you run experiments, everything has to be about experiments.
If we were doing things
where the right answer was already known,
hey, let's just make V6 of this train or this satellite.
Whatever, we made V5, V6 isn't gonna be that different,
you probably know what we need to do.
Moonshots by definition are over the horizon.
We can't see where they're going
so my ideas aren't much better than random
and neither are yours.
And we need to get really comfortable
with the fact that we just need to try something.
And we're gonna be wrong but we'll learn from it
and then we can repeat and we'll eventually get
to somewhere pretty exciting.
Running the experiments is itself hard
but the really hard part is after we run the experiment,
I need you, however passionate you were
while you were working on your project,
we now need to step back
and if you're running the project,
I need you to do it with me
so that we can dispassionately assess,
we just got some data from the world, right?
What does this mean?
Should we keep doing this project?
If you're too personally tied in,
emotionally tied in to what this thing is,
then we're not going to solve the problem
that we aspire to solve as fast as we could
because you're blinded by how attached you've become
to your solution to this project, so--
So sometimes you have to kill projects, right?
Sometimes you have to kill projects,
but that entire process of running the experiments,
getting out into the world in carefully sandboxed ways,
getting feedback, no, physics doesn't like your solution,
or the ecosystems we'd be entering don't like your solution,
or society's not happy with your solution.
We need to hear that,
we need to be really honest with ourselves
while there's still time to pivot,
now let's learn and repeat.
So that whole process of being passionate
while we try things,
but then dispassionate while we assess them
is a sort of central cultural points that we have.
And if you think about it,
in order to take moonshots,
you need huge amounts of audacity
but that would be a disaster
if you don't have equivalent amounts of humility.
The audacity let's you try things that sound crazy
and the humility reminds you you're probably not right,
and allows you then to be honest
about each of these iterations.
Did that really work?
No, I guess not, let's try something different.
So how do you get them to inhabit that head space?
To be both extremely audacious,
kinda weird, kinda out there,
but also able to then sort of
mathematically break down what they were doing
and whether it works? Well, part of it is,
and this is a third example,
something that I think is really close to our hearts,
is being radically positive
and seeing things as possible.
If we see a problem over there and we wanna go solve it,
let's have huge audacity that we can solve that problem,
huge optimism that we can solve that problem.
That does not mean your current solution
is gonna solve that problem.
But if I can get you to think,
this is back to long term again,
really long term we're going to go solve
a piece of the climate crisis issue,
let's set our sights on that and then,
being optimistic about that very long term thing frees us up
where we don't need to be right today,
because it's in service of succeeding in the very long term.
A lot of what you talk about seems sort of psychological.
You're really thinking about how people think
and spending a lot of time kind of cultivating
the right types of mindsets and approaches.
How does that kind of come through in your culture?
I think that's everything.
Everyone who's ever run a business understands
that it's almost entirely about the people.
Whatever your business is,
it's almost entirely about the people.
And once you acknowledge
it's almost entirely about the people,
let's say in our case, our business's innovation,
well, let's ask people to innovate
and then let's watch why they don't do the things
that you wish they would do.
You ask them to do this,
and then they run off and they do this.
Well, what's the difference?
This is the lip service, isn't lip service good enough?
No, it's not good enough.
They're listening to the emotional paths of least resistance
that you create in an organization
and they won't do this thing you're asking them to do
until you align your actual culture
with the things you're asking them to do.
So if I want you to take really big smart risks
which is a kind of innovation,
that means most of the time, you will run an experiment,
and the answer will be nope, nothing under that rock,
but you're going to run the experiment
in your mind ahead of time and think,
what's gonna happen to me when I run the experiment
and then I get a zero?
What is my boss gonna say?
What are my peers gonna say?
If the culture does anything but actively reward you
for running a great experiment
that was a smart experiment to run
even though you got a zero,
you will never run one of those experiments again
and innovation is dead in the building.
So I think understanding why people shy away
from being weird in the right ways
and taking big, smart risks,
why it's hard for them to try things iteratively,
the pressures to look smart
by doing it right the first time,
why it's hard to step back from the passion
that you're working on and be dispassionate about that,
if you don't understand why people are
sort of inefficient in these ways,
then the innovation just won't happen.
Can you give me an example of a failure?
Step us through-- Sure.
How you handle failure and make us feel okay about it.
So, one of the most exciting things that we've ever done
was someone proposed that we make a box
that would turn seawater into methanol.
And the argument was if we could just turn seawater
into methanol, then basically,
you would run a carbon negative process,
the sea sucks the O2 out of the air,
holds it in the ocean, you pull it out of the ocean,
you make a hydrocarbon out of it,
you burn in the four billion gas tanks
that are in the world,
and those aren't going away anytime soon,
that puts CO2 back in the air
but the whole process is carbon neutral,
that's real save-the-world kinda stuff.
Unbelievably exciting, could we really make that?
Took two years, we actually had something
that was smaller than this stage
that was making methanol out of seawater.
People were crying they were so excited.
Nine months-- But?
Nine months after that, we had to acknowledge
that the most optimistic view we could get,
now that we had the details of how it worked,
maybe $15 gallon-of-gas equivalent.
[Sandra] Ooh.
That's not gonna save the world, that's just not.
We could pretend it will, but it won't.
We could just deny all the work we just did
and say oh, I'm sure we'll get to $5
even though we just sorted out
that it's probably not gonna get under 15.
So what we did, which I think was the right thing to do,
was we closed the project down
and we published a business part
of our learnings in a business magazine,
in Fast Company, and we published
in the International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control
what we had learned from a science perspective,
and removing that from the table, freeing up those people.
The woman who was running that project started
on another project which was
in the geothermal heat pump space,
and that one has gone on, it's now called Dandelion,
it's out in the world and it's thriving.
So she wouldn't have started that project
if we hadn't closed this down.
And every time we end a project,
it's not that we don't care
about mitigating the climate crisis,
it's that we want to so badly
that we're willing to stop doing something,
no matter how good it makes us feel,
because the short-term brutal honesty is in service
of this really long-term goal of solving this problem.
How long did it take you to reach that conclusion?
You being the team.
I mean, it was 2.5 years from start to finish,
probably nine months from when they had a working prototype
to when the techno-economics were like, they said,
and this was a great example where they said,
it's just not gonna happen.
They were very sad, but we didn't have to put them
in a headlock and shake our finger at them,
they came and told us this.
In retrospect, do you think it could have happened faster?
Maybe a little bit, but I'm pretty confident
it would have gone slower almost anywhere else.
So that's not to say that it can't be even better.
We have a joke at X that we're the worst moonshot factory
in the world, except for all the other ones.
Which is sort of our way of keeping ourselves audacious
and humble at the same time,
remembering to keep working on things,
but also have some pride in how things are going.
And another thing, some people from that team
and some of the money that that freed up moved
into another climate-crisis mitigation
and adaptation-oriented project that we now have,
which happens to be in the food production space,
a computational agriculture project.
So, every time the ashes are there,
that's an opportunity for the phoenix.
So, we talked about a few climate projects,
or at least mentioned them.
I'm curious, it seems like there's an emergent theme,
a focus on climate change at X
and I'm wondering to what degree that's deliberate,
or just emergent.
I would call it emergent, I would say our goal is to find
and solve huge problems in the world.
And the climate crisis is the single biggest
problem the world has right now,
so that's not a denial of the world's other problems
and we are working on lots of things
besides the climate crisis.
But it's taking a lot of space in our windshield right now
because it's just so big.
There are also a lot of opportunities for
solving multiple problems at the same time.
The climate crisis, at this point,
touches on so many other of the world's problems.
So for example, the computational agriculture problem
I was talking about, I mean,
if you had a view like from a satellite
and you could zoom all the way down
to an individual strawberry,
and you could see exactly how it was doing everyday,
you could see whether there was a pest
that had just showed up or a little bit of fungus or mold,
if you knew exactly whether
that one strawberry needed a tiny bit more water or not,
it would totally change food production.
Now, that's not possible, you can't zoom in,
even from a drone you couldn't see that specifically enough.
But we've built a plant buggy
that can go out into the field and look at every
individual plant that's out there in these huge fields
so that farmers can start to manage food,
can we roll the video about the plant buggy,
if you have that one?
So that you can look at these individual plants
and let farmers start to manage,
instead of on a 1000-acre basis,
start to manage on a per-plant basis.
That has the chance,
this is one of these acupressure points in society.
You could justify the existence
of this moonshot purely on the basis of food production
which is a huge problem for the world.
But you could also argue this on the basis
that 30% of the world's CO2 output happens
because of making, moving, and serving food,
and the climate crisis is not gonna get fixed in time
so we need adaptation solutions.
And so if you want to find ways to breed better plants,
if you have a farmer over here
who has learned something about
how to take care of crops with half the water,
now that they have to, how is that knowledge gonna move
to farmers across the rest of the world?
And a system like this might support that.
So, we don't have them up anymore
but some dumb questions about the plant buggy,
why are they so big?
What's in there, what are they doing?
Yeah, I feel like I was so happy they were so small.
[audience laughing]
Honestly, so--
Maybe they should be bigger.
First of all, I mean, I think it's really neat,
they extend up and down so they can get their tummies
really close to the plants, but they can also lift up.
They're on four wheels but they can lift up
so they're over things like corn, or wheat, or grape vines,
they can sort of go over things that are very high.
They can also change their wheelbase.
So being able to be very flexible
about what they're looking at is one of the things
that sort of causes them to have a little bit extra there.
There's also, these are not products,
these are learning prototypes.
So there's like an everything-and-the-kitchen-sink
on those right now, honestly,
because the teams have this attitude,
who knows what's really gonna solve the problem?
Here's a little example.
There's leaves that cover very efficiently,
and on purpose, plants like melons, for example.
Even if you're standing right over the melon,
you cannot see the melon
'cause it's covered with these big leaves.
What's gonna cause you to see through that?
Should you get a leaf blower
and just move the leaves so you can see them?
Should you try ultrasound or x-rays?
There isn't an obvious right answer
and there are thousands of those things.
These are just unsolved problems,
nobody knows the answer to it
and so what we're trying to do right now
is to build platforms that can allow us
to work with the farmers and understand this
so that over time we can help them
to start managing their fields on a per-plant basis.
So you're kinda just in this data collection stage,
like take it all in and see what matters?
Yeah, I mean, we already, I think,
are being helpful to the farmers that we're working with
but there's a ton still for us to learn over time.
The first step would have to be noticing
that there's a pest there.
But if you could see the pest,
imagine instead of just carpet-bombing your fields
with pesticides, if you could just go
[softly mimics spraying] on that one little spot
because there's a little pest there,
one billionth as much pesticide, literally,
might do the same job as carpet-bombing your fields
if you're seeing them in the right times
and spraying them at the right moment.
These things do not spray the pests right now
but that's the kind of thing
that they could do in the future.
But the first thing is we have
to get really good at seeing the pest.
How far are you from the point
where you do the dispassionate math on this project
and see how it scales up?
So, the point about the dispassion is true
at the project level, but it's sorta fractal,
it turtles all the way down, if you will.
They're running experiments all the time,
like the one I was just describing with the melons, right?
Where, for example, I was the one
who suggested the leaf blower,
they tried it, maybe they were just humoring me,
turned out that was a disaster.
It kinda doesn't work very well to move the leaves
but the bigger problem is it kicks up huge amounts of dust
and pisses off the farmers, not a solution.
Okay, good to know, cross that off the list.
So that's like a little dispassion moment within,
and that would've been nice,
I don't care that it was my idea,
would've been nice 'cause it's cheap,
leaf blowers are not expensive, right?
But it didn't work, so we throw it away.
So the dispassion's happening on a weekly basis.
That's not a once-a-year-should-we-continue kinda,
I mean, it's also at the project level,
but it's a daily, even, occurrence for these teams.
What do you look for in the next projects
that you wanna see coming out of X?
It's really nice when,
I described huge problem with the world,
the radical solution, the breakthrough technology,
but it is particularly nice if you can tell a story
about 10 or 15 years from now,
here's how we hoped to change the world,
a huge problem that we hoped to have solved.
And here's a first plausible step along that journey
which by itself would get us a lot of experience
out in the world, might even function
as a kind of beachhead for a business
if it was set up as an other bet.
That helps us to believe that it won't be wait 15 years
and then open the box and see
if there's something really good inside,
'cause that's not how we want it to be.
That's an example of the kind of sort of next-level thing
that we're looking for in these projects.
Do you have any pet projects or ideas,
or spaces that you want it to be in?
That you haven't gotten to explore yet?
There's so many.
I mean, there certainly are ones,
like we've taken quite a few runs at the battery space,
especially grid scale storage.
The number of projects that we've otherwise run into
were the energy density of batteries,
or the volumetric density of the batteries,
or just the cost to be able to hold a megawatt hour,
or have a megawatt of capacity for the batteries.
Any of those things, rate limits,
all of these other moonshots that come up.
So in service of a lot of climate-crisis issues
and non climate-crisis issues,
batteries are sort of this linchpin
that we keep coming back to, that's an example.
But food production has been on our radar screen
for a long time, we hadn't found any, now we have several,
but you just sort of have to wait
till the right constellation of things comes together.
We're always looking at the future of computation.
I think that we will not, 20, 30 years from now,
have computers looking like they currently look like.
So that doesn't tell us what to do,
but that's a space where the world is gonna change a lot
in the next 20 or 30 years.
There's a lot of things like that.
Thank you so much--
My pleasure. Astro Teller.
[applause]
Thanks.
